Napoleon can be ambitious to the point of rudeness. He adapts his strategy to the situation, but prefers to attack with large armies of fully upgraded units, especially cavalry. He taunts his enemies frequently and may not follow his allies' lead.
Queen Elizabeth can be aloof, aristocratic and formal. She is a dependable if not overly warm ally. She understands the value of a strong economy and a versatile navy.

Queen Isabella of Castille is supportive bordering on flirtatious with her allies but mocks and chastises her enemies. She makes full use of the versatility of the Spanish army, but never leaves her colonies undefended. She is unlikely to take dangerous risks.

Ivan the Terrible is ruthless, sinister and threatening. He taunts enemy and ally alike. He likes to attack early and swarm his opponents with infantry and emphasizes large armies at the expense of technological development.

Maurice of Orange is all business. Every conversation is a transaction and every decision revolves around profit. He views war as a necessary part of business. He looks for Trade Routes when possible, but always defends his colonies.

Henry the Navigator is calculating and far-sighted. He emphasizes exploration and economic development over military dominance. He can take offense easily and can be something of a zealot when dealing with non-Portuguese.

Frederick the Great is proud and confident. He expresses regret when his men die in battle, but does not hesitate to use his entire military might to accomplish even the smallest task. Frederick will not neglect his economy, but believes in attacking aggressively.
Suleiman the Magnificent is scholarly and even-tempered. He balances colony development, trade, improvements and military. He is gracious to allies but may underestimate opponents.
Aristocrat: I can see how you think that might be better.
Aristocrat: I have heard you feedback, and ignored it.
Girl: Mommy, where do babies come from?
Artist: This piece? I call it man with no job.
Torchy: I might look good, but I have burns on two-thirds of my body.
Butcher: They call me Schwettie. Care for a famous Schwettie sausage?
Nice Lady: And now the money just rolls in.
Beefeater: No, no, I'm a vegetarian.
Jack: That's not a razor. This is a razor!
Policeman: Let me introduce you to Billy. Billy club!
Strelet: The health plan's not good, but I do get to beat people up.
Strelet: My five brothers were all Streltsy too.
Strelet: I come from a family of seventy. We're all Streltsy.
Vendor: Come and get your cookies. Cheap. Slightly used.
Vendor: You break it, I break you.
Vendor: Turnips! Fresh turnips! Old ones too.
Vendor: Eel! Get your fresh eel right here!

Andes is a mountainous region with the warring factions starting dangerously close. A Trade Route with three Trading Post sites separates the teams. Four native settlements are on the northern part of the map. Allying with all the Natives is potentially powerful.

California is a beautiful area along the Pacific Ocean. Towering redwoods line the shore, giving way first to mountains, then to the Mojave Desert to the east. Native settlements of Klamath and Nootka are on opposite map sides, and a long Trade Route traverses the edge of the Mojave Desert.

Northwest Territory is a green and rainy region along the Pacific Coast of North America. Resources are plentiful, and Klamath and Nootka villages can be found nestled among the trees. Control the crossings and the resource-rich region across the main river to ensure victory.
Grants archers a new attack against buildings using flaming arrows.
All infantry units deal more damage in melee mode.
All Cavalry deal more damage to artillery.
Traditional armor enables your Lakota Warriors to be more resistant to siege-type damage (inflicted by units such as Artillery).
All siege weapon armor increased, making them far more resistant to ranged fire.

Hispaniola: a large island surrounded by warm tropical seas.

Settlements: Caribs
Outlaws: Pirate

Surrounded by sea, Hispaniola promises conflict on both land and water. Inland, Carib tribes live in the jungles, around the base of an impassable mountain.\n \nExtra starting crates of Food will help you jump start your early economy. Whales in the western bay are a strategic secondary source of Coin.

If we can avoid patrols and take out the tents in Trenton, we should catch them off guard.
We don't have the manpower to take on his main army.
Build some fires to trick Cornwallis into thinking we've made camp for the night.
Excellent. Move out and attack his rear guard.
Take out the rear guard now!
The rear guard in Princeton has been destroyed.
Early automatic-fire weapon. Better against infantry than buildings.
Revolt, and become a new nation!
My father Nathaniel Black was a hero of the American Revolution, who fought with the colonial army at Bunker Hill, Trenton and Saratoga...
...and he was there at the end, at Yorktown.
But his story begins six years earlier, in his village where he had grown up.
The six nations of the Confederacy split apart as the fires of the American Revolution spread northward.
Nathaniel's world would never be the same.
So the Seneca have joined with the Mohawk?
Yes. Both tribes think the British will protect them.
This is a white man's war. We must counsel the Seneca and the Mohawk to stay out of the fight.
Uncle Ká:nien, if we don't choose a side, one will be chosen for us. We must defend our homes.
It's not a matter for young warriors to decide.
No more, Nathaniel. You will accompany me to the villages of our brothers. You will be silent. You will learn.
Colonel Kuechler, here are the captives the Mohawk took from the Oneida village.
How many warriors can your village muster?
You will know when they come for your head.
Do not mistake me for some soft Englishman.
You may know how to make war against your own kind, but you face Hessians now.
My orders are to cleanse these woods of rebels. If your people get in my way, they die.
The six nation Confederacy was broken.
Some joined the British, while others, helped the colonial cause.
Whether he was driven by a desire to live up to his father John's legacy, or he simply wanted to learn more about the outside world, I never knew.
When the call went out for militia volunteers, Nathaniel and other young men from the frontier headed south, to Boston...
I'm Captain Nathaniel Black. Where are we needed?
The British have landed near Breed's Hill - follow me!
In the early days of the Revolution, the Americans were always on the defensive - pushed out of Boston, out of New York.
George Washington took command of the colonials, determined to make a real army out of ragtag militiamen.
But even Washington's leadership could not stop the British tide.
By December of 1776, the Americans had been pushed back across the Delaware to McKonkey's Ferry.
It was there my father's militia joined them.
General Washington...I'm honored to meet you, sir.
The honor is mine, Captain Black. Your father John was a good man.
I would be pleased to have you think the same of me one day.
I'm sorry we missed the fight in New York.
Perhaps you would have changed the outcome.
But you're here in time to help us turn the tide. The Hessian garrison has settled into their winter quarters in Trenton.
Yes. They're camped right across the Delaware.
I've got unfinished business with the Hessians.
Good. Let's give them a holiday to remember.

Completing secondary objectives will help you reach your primary objective. You cannot train Settlers from your Town Center. However, your Miners and any Settlers you send from your Home City can gather from any resource crates you find or steal.

There may be a back route through the canyons near the Sheriff's base, through which the Lakota War Chief can be more easily rescued. After you free the Lakota War Chief from the stockade, you must bring him to the flagged area in the light blue Lakota village to collect experience for the rescue.

Get more soldiers ready. Put everything we have into destroying that town center.
At the dawn of the American Revolution, the nations of the Haudenosaunee (referred to as the Iroquois Confederacy by European settlers) faced their greatest challenge.
Nonahkee has been kidnapped! Nathaniel and Ká:nien race to her rescue, hoping to discover the identity of her captors.
Nonahkee has been rescued, but her reunion with her son Nathaniel will be a brief one...
In the early days of the Revolution, the colonials were pushed back time and time again - until Washington took command.
The British army's summer push down the Hudson River Valley seemed unstoppable - but their supply lines were thinly stretched.
A hard winter awaited the colonial army at Valley Forge...but Nathaniel's militia was there to help.
Throughout the war, Colonel Kuechler eluded Nathaniel - until finally, they would face off near Morristown.
When the French entered the war on the American side, the colonists were finally able to throw off Britain's yoke.
Light infantry with low hitpoints, but a long-ranged attack. Good against infantry.
Automatically generates units of your choice.
Put them to work gathering resources, and keep our men in the redoubt.
We'll need to train more soldiers if we're going to hold off the British.
The British will be attacking soon.
Sir! Lookouts report the British are about three minutes away.
British troops have been spotted in Boston. They'll be here any minute.
Generates resources or artillery automatically. Configure it to produce different things. Can only be sent from the Home City.
We need to take out their outposts to clear an area for our forward base.
Good work, men. Supplies have arrived for Washington's army. Let's set up our town center and get to work right away.
The French have sent word that they have arrived to assist us.
This base will do just fine. Train an army and drive the British from Yorktown!
The redoubts will need to be destroyed before we can hope to penetrate Yorktown.
All of the outposts along the river must be destroyed for more of the French Navy to arrive.
Take these petards and destroy the British outposts along the river.
The French Navy is waiting out in the Atlantic. Once the York river is safe we will be able to attack.
We can send more ships if more outposts are destroyed.
The men won't last long working out in this cold.
The bakers in town will give us food, though it won't be free.
Money shouldn't be an issue. I'm sure my grandchildren will understand...
We'll just have to make sure we avoid British patrols.
Perhaps these Haudenosaunee can help us out.
Get that food cart back to the camp.
Watch out for British patrols while you're heading back to Valley Forge.
We have enough food. Get those huts built.
General, the food stores are full!
We'll never last the winter in these tents. We need to get the men busy building proper quarters.
Good. Now we'll need to concentrate on getting enough food to feed the troops.
The colonial army has no money right now.
Maybe some of the local tribes have some food they can give us.
Get back to the fires if it gets too cold.
Excellent work everyone. The colonial army has survived to fight another day.
We have barely enough supplies for our own survival.
But perhaps some of our people can help out.
We have no food to spare, but my people will hunt for you.
Yes, these should do nicely, General.
Kuechler does have a small base here. Let's destroy it.
Quick! We must use the route he's shown us to reach Kuechler's siege army!
Kuechler's siege army is on the move!
Kuechler's siege army is halfway to Morristown.
Kuechler's army has begun to siege Morristown.
Kuechler's siege army is smashing its way east through Morristown.
We've got to stop them before they destroy the Morristown capitol!
Cavalry are the most effective units against artillery.
Better watch our flanks; Kuechler knows these swamps better than we do.
Kuechler's troops are attacking our base through a southeast route.
I'm not sure what Kuechler is up to on our north flank, but I don't want another surprise like we had at Bound Brook.
These artillery pieces from my cannonworks should help take care of whatever you find up there.
As you destroy Hessian buildings I will supply you with additional artillery units.
Here are more artillery units to help you, Nathaniel.
Here is another artillery piece, Nathaniel.
Kuechler has begun to attack the capitol! You must destroy his siege army!
Nathaniel, here are my swiftest cavalry. Use them to help stop Kuechler!
You will never stop me in time!
No - I will not be defeated by you! NO!
The Hessians have held me prisoner - thank you for rescuing me.
The Hessian's main base is farther north. He has been working secretly to assemble a large siege army.
Colonel Kuechler plans to advance with his siege army to Morristown on a secret path through a swamp west of here. He means to destroy the capitol!
I will show you the only route to pursue Kuechler's siege army before he destroys the capitol.
You've done it! Kuechler and his Hessians are defeated.

Perform a Green Corn Ceremony to boost unit speed.

Perform a Town Ceremony to increase building hitpoints and attack.

The food and wood here are scarce. We'll have to rely on our trading posts.
The scouts report bandits and rival miners are willing to fight for control of these hills.
We must protect the mining camps!
We've destroyed an enemy barracks - good work.
That war hut has been destroyed.
One of our trading posts is under attack!
We've done it!  We've taken out every barracks in the Black Hills.
We can't afford to lose too many more trading posts.
You know what's bad about gold? It attracts flies.
The vermin 'round here want to destroy the mining camps.
Your job is to protect the mining camps, while taking out their barracks.
They've destroyed one of our mining camps!
Another mining camp has been destroyed.
You'll never make deputy fighting like that.
You allowed three mining camps to be destroyed. Never send a boy to do a man's job.
Light artillery. Better against infantry than buildings.
A falconet that doesn't belong to you - yet.
A mortar that doesn't belong to you - yet.
A cannon that doesn't belong to you - yet.
A rocket that doesn't belong to you - yet.
My scouts report Colonel Kuechler's Hessians are moving on our north flank.
Intercept him before he cuts our supply line.
I knew you were the man for the job.
This war, this revolution - it's larger than any one man.
I know Kuechler has wronged you personally.
But your father's desire for revenge led him to his death.
General Washington, my father gave his life to protect the colonies. I would do the same, without hesitation.
Your enlistment is up next month. You could go back home to your family.
My place is with the Colonial Army until our nation is free.
I'll fight at your side until the war is won.
After the battles at Trenton and Princeton, Nathaniel's militia was sent north, into the wilderness along the Canadian border.
His men skirmished with the British up and down the Hudson Valley throughout the spring.
But the fighting was indecisive until late summer, near Saratoga.
There's the British column. They're headed to Albany.
Captain...if they get that far, they'll cut our army in two.
Send scouts to mark their route. We'll whittle them down and force them to fight here.
After Colonel Kuechler's death, Nathaniel kept his promise to Washington.
And he was there at the end, at Yorktown in 1781, face to face with the redcoats for the last time.
Saratoga was a great victory, but there were many trials ahead.
The British and the Hessians pushed back hard, defeating the Americans at Brandywine and Germantown.
In December, the colonial army retreated to its winter camp at Valley Forge and settled in to wait for spring.
General, we can't sit here all winter. The men will starve.
We have no choice. We must reorganize and refit.
Soon we'll face Cornwallis' army head-on. The new recruits need training.
They need food more than training.
I can find my way through enemy lines and bring back the supplies we need.
An excellent plan, but a dangerous one, Captain. Be careful.
War Rifle attack and hitpoints increased.
Axe Rider attack and hitpoints increased.
Axe Rider attack and hitpoints increased.

Painted Desert: Open desert with plentiful resources but no trade route.

Settlements: Apache, Navajo, Comanche
Outlaws: Comanchero, Pistolero

Painted Desert is a lonely open range with scattered mesas and rich ore deposits. Hunting is plentiful, but Wood is a little scarcer. Lost cows can also be found wandering among the mesas. Four Apache and Navajo villages line the center of the map.

Destroy all of the Hessian Town Centers.
The Town Centers in the Hessian bases are easily destroyed by artillery attacks.
Kuechler's army has destroyed the Morristown Capitol. We've failed.
A tree such as maple or white pine. Harvest for Wood.
Native boat that can attack or transport units.
Native boat that can attack or transport units.
Gather the nearby Wood to light this.
Diverse tropical trees including palms and strangler figs. Harvest for Wood.
Race to build 3 Forts before the British build 3 Forts.
Destroy the Bridge of Boats to delay Kuechler's arrival.

The British Fort Wagons travel along the Trade Route stopping at the Trading Posts as they move south. It is safest to attack the wagons as they travel between these posts, but watch out for British patrols.

After you reach the Fortress Age, you can train Fort Wagons from your Town Center. The British will also be getting wagons. Forts are strong and have a lot of hitpoints, but Fort Wagons and Fort foundations are very fragile and much more easily destroyed, attack these whenever you can.
The Bridge of Boats can be found near one of the British Trading Posts.
When this bridge is destroyed Kuechler's soldiers will be delayed while they secure another way across the Hudson River.
There, now the Hessians will have to cross the river somewhere else.
Too bad for him - we've already destroyed his bridge.
One more wagon to go. Send for the reinforcements!
When we reach the Fortress Age we will be able to train fort wagons from our town center. It will be expensive, but my family's money can help.
Reinforcements! You couldn't have arrived at a better time.
It'll be enough. The British will be building up to claim this territory. Let's build some forts of our own.
We can train fort wagons now.
The British have completed a fort!
The British have two forts. We need to mount an attack, or admit defeat.
We've stopped the British advance! Send runners to Washington!
Captain Black, concede Saratoga or you will lose your entire command.
Nathaniel, the first wagon is right behind me.
This was all that could be spared, Captain.
Remember, we can train fort wagons at the town center.
Nathaniel, we have found Kuechler's outpost and the bridge of boats.
The third British fort is up. We've lost.
Builds buildings, but is consumed by doing so.
The War Arrow! War Hut units train much more quickly.
Canoes and War Canoes become cheaper.

Knowledge of wildlife gains you food. You get slightly more than 100 food for every minute the game has lasted so far.

Your colonial soldiers can gather Wood and build huts, but the harsh winter will take its toll. Move your men to the fires to heal them.
Without Settlers, you will have to find other ways to collect Food. Nathaniel can buy carts of Food in Philadelphia, and others in the area may be willing to help.
Destroy the British Fort on Barren Hill.
Now that the worst of the winter has passed, build up an army and destroy the British Fort.
Survive the winter and strike back at the British.
We've survived the worst of the winter.
The fort is well-protected. Be careful.
Keep at it, men! The fort is nearly down.
We need to strike the British quickly.
Gather the men and take out the fort on Barren Hill.
That's Kuechler - he's off to the east. He'll have to cross the Hudson River to meet up with the British.
The bridge is out. We will have to find another way to cross the Hudson River.
The British only need one more fort.
A soldier who can gather Wood, but not other resources. He looks cold.
This wagon is carrying Food. Move it to Valley Forge.
Grand Canyon: deep chasm flanked by starting areas.
Grants Tupi warriors. All Natives are Legendary.
All units gain slightly more hitpoints.
Good work. Two more forts and we'll control the battlefield.
One more fort and we'll win the battle. Look sharp!
Stop the British advance to Albany.
Destroy all of the York River Towers with Petards to get more French Monitors. Use the Monitors to destroy the Fixed Guns.
These ships will help you shell the city.
You can see everything your enemies can see!

Guide the Food Cart safely back to the flagged area inside the Valley Forge camp.
Another food cart is ready to go back to Valley Forge.
Get that food back to camp. The men are hungry.
The food in this cart will help our soldiers. Get it to Valley Forge now.
That tower is preventing help from reaching Valley Forge. We should destroy it.
Thank you. We never would have made it past that tower.
We lost our way in the storm. Can you lead us to Valley Forge?
We got lost in the pass during the storm. Thank you for rescuing us.

Trunion invention makes artillery more mobile.
A dangerous outlaw with a pistol.
A dangerous outlaw with a gun, strong against Heavy Infantry.
A dangerous Pirate who is quick on his feet. Ideal for early raids. Good against skirmishers and artillery.

You the Falcon Company man? Chayton Black?
Welcome to Fort Laramie. I'm Billy Holme, the quartermaster.
Colonel Carrington asked me to escort you up the Bozeman trail.
I hear Falcon's going to open up a couple of new stations in these parts.
You know, you're not what I expected. You Indian?
My great-grandmother was Haudenosaunee, and...my father was Lakota.
Don't matter to me what you are, but you might want to keep that to yourself.
The Lakota, they ain't too popular around here.
My father died when I was young. I was raised by my mother.
I'm sorry, kid. I didn't mean to...
Escort the Covered Wagon from Fort Laramie to the Trading Post.
Good sites for Trading Posts can be found further up the trail. Watch out for attacks.
Chayton Black can build Trading Posts. Keep him safe.
A Covered Wagon is on the way from Fort Laramie to your new trading post. Keep it safe.
Another good site for a Trading Post can be found further up the Bozeman Trail.

A second Covered Wagon is on the way. Keep it safe, but watch your new Town Center too. You will be able to advance to the next age and train military units once the second Wagon reaches its destination safely.
Own two Trading Posts when the scenario ends.
There are only two free Trading Post sites on the map. Fort Laramie's Trading Post does not count.
A successful New Year Festival provides you with 2000 experience points.
Transforms into a mighty Fort for frontier defense.
Precursors to the Inca, the Huari still control parts of the Andes.
Nice work tracking down Crazy Horse, kid. Just like the old days, huh?
What have you done? The Lakota were ready to negotiate.
You're wrong. The Lakota murder anyone they can get their hands on.
Crazy Horse said the miners broke the truce first. Is it true?
It's war now, and the Lakota are gunning for us. Come on.
They should have kept to the trail. This is Lakota country.
To butcher men like that...it's wrong.
I saw a lot of men die at Antietam and Gettysburg, kid. It's never pretty, but you get used to it.
Let's find the ones who did this.
This morning. It's a hard trip up from Boulder City, but I didn't want to miss the opening of the station.
I couldn't have done it without my friend, Billy Holme.
I met him. I think he made a pass at me.
Those Lakota we fought - it was personal for them. They were so angry.
The Lakota aren't what I expected. You told me my father was a gentle man.
He was. The Lakota are just like other people, Chayton - some gentle, some not.
This peace between the settlers and the Lakota...it won't last.
But it's peace, for a while.
We can get the resources we most need by changing the orders at our trading posts.
You have no right to take the gold from these hills.
These hills are just ugly with gold. Why should they have it all for themselves?
It looks like word of the gold got back to Spain. Now you've got some Spanish miners to fight off too, kid.
The Colonials are ambushing our wagons - stop them!
After Red Cloud's War, the uneasy truce between the Lakota and the settlers held for almost a decade.
When I retired from Falcon Company, I put my son in charge. For years, he was so busy he almost forgot about Red Cloud's War.
Until one day, when an old friend called him back to a town in the shadow of the Black Hills.
The elected representative of the law in these parts, and your humble servant.
Good to see you again, Billy. I rode up as soon as I got your letter. What'd you want to show me?
Heard you're in charge of Falcon Company now. Thought you might want to see what we found out here.
Lots of it. And it's all ours.
We're going to get rich, and you can be a part of it.
The Lakota will be back, and next time, in force.
It's greed, is all. Everyone wants our gold.
The bandits were after the gold, but the Lakota...this is their land. We shouldn't be here.
Then get out there and track down your old pal Crazy Horse. Try to talk some sense into him.
I will. We have to stop this before it becomes a war.
You want to tell me why, Billy?
You know why. You saw the mines.
It's the claim of a lifetime. I would have been rich.
The land belongs to the Lakota. If it had belonged to the settlers, would you have killed them too?
Their blood's the same color. It's gold that matters, kid. Only gold.
Nothing I say is going to stop Custer from butchering your Lakota friends.
Provides a hitpoint and gathering rate boost to nearby units.
Provides a hitpoint boost to nearby military units.
Bridge of boats across the river.
Ranged raiding cavalry. Good against cavalry.
Bridge of boats across the river.
Sneaky assassin. Highly effective against mercenaries, Explorers, War Chiefs, and Monks.
Heals injured units and are also effective in combat. Warrior Priests are extremely effective when occupying the Community Plaza.
Powerful heavy artillery from the foundries of Europe.
Ships a number of Li'l Bombards.
You have revolted from your mother country!
Maybe Holme was right; could be a tough fight to get to Uncle Frank. Maybe these townsfolk will help us out.
There's a lot of hunting in these lands.
The Lakota can support a large army with all these buffalo.
We can use this cart to clear a path back to the town.
Run that black powder wagon into one of the weapons caches to clear a path.
Another cart! Use it to clear some of those trees.
At last! I need to speak to you. I...
They're too strong. We have to pull back.
You can try, kid, but don't expect them to just let you waltz in.
The people in this town will help you out, but I've got something I gotta do in the meantime.
You want me to burn down a village? They haven't done anything!
I can't attack women and children.
Without that fort, you're too exposed to conduct raids.
They're too strong. We don't have the forces to hold them back.
We need to get that fort up, and to do that we need more wood.
Get out there and protect the folks gathering wood.
The fort is up! Now we can clear those raiders off the land.
Get out there and take out that village.
Not yet. Besides, we can't claim the gold until they're off this land.
I've been patient, kid, but I'm getting tired of your attitude.
You're either with us or against us. What's it gonna be?
I thought I taught you better than this, kid.
Bring Chayton to Uncle Frank's camp.
There are many outlaws between you and Uncle Frank. You will need military help to fight your way through.
Protect the Settlers gathering Wood for the fort.

Send soldiers to the forest to guard the Settlers against enemy attacks. The Wood they collect will be used to build the fort. Set your Trading Posts to deliver resources so you can train additional defensive units.
You will need to build a sizable army in order to take out the village.
Work with the Lakota and direct their forces against the fort.
Holme is hiding somewhere in these hills. We'll earn the trust of the local people, and they'll help us root him out.
We've established a strong military encampment here, but we have no villagers. These miners will help us gather what we need from any resource crates we can find.
We've freed some Lakota braves. Now we must bring them to the flagged area in the Lakota village.
The bandits in this area are running supply wagons of stolen goods through here  Kill them and task our miners to collect the resources.
Destroy that bandit's supply wagon. We need the resources it's carrying.
The Lakota will trust us once we've earned enough experience.
Holme has captured several Lakota braves and their War Chief. We should rescue them and return them to the Lakota village.
We can build a trading post on this trade route to gain more experience.
There are renegade outlaws crawling all over these hills. The Lakota will be grateful for every one we eliminate.
A camp of outlaws! Clear them out and we'll take their resources.
It looks like we've found Holme's camp.
We've destroyed Sheriff Holme's town center, but we must still earn the respect of the Lakota before our task is done.
Holme's bandits have overrun our base. We've lost.
You're trapped, Holme. There's no escape.
You have earned my respect, Chayton Black.
There are caves to the north and west of the village. Your enemy may be inside. We will show you a way in.
We have revealed the secret entrance to the caves. Our enemy is hiding somewhere within.
Holme is clever, and may have hidden strength.
There is Holme. His life belongs to you now.
The sheriff's holed up with his bandits in the hills. Most of the locals went with him.
You look like a Lakota to me.
My name is Chayton Black. I own the railroad.
George Armstrong Custer. I've been sent to put a stop to the Indian raids in these parts.
Sheriff Holme's been stirring up trouble between the Lakota and the miners.
He wants to drive the Lakota off their land to claim the gold for himself.
The Indian problem is a lot bigger than some two-bit local sheriff, Mr. Black.
The Lakota and Cheyenne will return to their reservations, or they'll answer to me.
I'll drag Holme back here, and you can hear the truth from him.
Do as you please. I'll be camped here for a while.
The supply trains are fifty miles back, and I'm not moving until my whole command's in position.
You've got your day, Black. Use it well.
Good, here come the militiamen. Let's get that wagon!
This spot is perfect. Keep me covered while I get a trading post built.
A covered wagon is heading up the trail from Fort Laramie.
We've got to protect it from the raiders.
We'll have to protect the new town center while we scout further up the trail for another good trading post site.
Another covered wagon is on the way.
We'll find a good spot for your trading post further up the trail.
Watch your back. This is a dangerous country.
Another covered wagon is on the way - look sharp!
They just keep comin'. We've got to take the fight to them if we're gonna secure the trail.
What has made them so angry?
We should be able to hire some men in the saloon here.
You walk a difficult path, young warrior. Be careful you do not slip and fall.
You have a warrior's spirit - but do you understand the cause for which you fight?
I will drive your railroad men from these lands.
We will defend this place with our lives.
I don't know, but they've been chasing us for days!
There are lots more men coming up behind us...please save them!
Stealth. Your units will be hidden from enemy units.

Three Cheyenne camps are nearby; find them and bring the War Chiefs to the Lakota town center. All of the Cheyenne camps are all south of the river, but may not be directly accessible. Each War Chief will contribute his forces to the fight once he has arrived at the Lakota town center.

General Custer will send some men ahead to scout out Medicine Tail Coulee. It will take them a while to reach the river crossing, but once there they will call for General Custer and his army. Use the time it takes them to travel to build up and defend against attacks.
General Custer has arrived. Use your warrior army to find and kill him.
Custer's Army has forward bases north of the river. Uncle Frank will send warriors when each of the two forward Town Centers is destroyed.

Destroy the revealed buildings to reduce the number of troops that General Custer will bring across the Little Bighorn River and into the Lakota settlement. You will have to fight through enemy towns to get to most of Custer's buildings.
Build three Trading Posts and upgrade the Trade Route.

If you need Wood for the Trading Posts, you can buy some at the Market. Build three Trading Posts on the Trade Route and then upgrade the route to a Railroad. Switching to Coin deliveries will increase your income so you can hire more mercenaries.
Watch out - there's a raiding party headed for our town.
Cannot switch to stealth mode when enemy units are nearby.
Destroying both hostile Camps will secure the trail. Both Camps are well-defended.
One minute until end of treaty!
The treaty has ended!  Fighting may begin!
Quick moving artillery. Strong against infantry.
During the treaty period, buildings may only be built close to the starting Town Centers.
In the nineteenth century, westward expansion slowed, not only in the face of fierce Native American resistance, but also in response to criminal activity.
Chayton and Holme have secured the trail, but the Reno Gang had escaped to continue their destruction of neighbouring Lakȟóta villages.
The Lakota, led by Uncle Frank, fought the U.S. Army to a standstill. The fragile truce would hold for almost a decade.
Chayton and Sheriff Holme have defended the gold mines - but what are the Lakota really after?
Holme's actions have dashed Chayton's hopes of a peace settlement. The Lakota are sure to respond in force.
The Lakota and the settlers are at each other's throats. Holme has fled with his bandits, leaving Chayton to pick up the pieces.
Holme is dead, but Custer is on the move. Is it too late to stop a war?
With two trading posts to protect, we'll have Fort Laramie's support. We can age up and train soldiers now.
Yeah, we won't be able to age up or train soldiers until we get a second trading post built. Let's move.

Orinoco: a tropical river map with crossings.

Settlements: Caribs, Maya, Zapotec
Outlaws: Pirate, Pistolero

Orinoco is a tropical region just north of the Amazon jungle. The teams are separated by the mighty Orinoco River, which empties into the Caribbean Sea to the north. Up to four different Native tribes can live in this area, including the Caribs, Maya, and Zapotec.

Araucania runs the length of South America's west coast and has plentiful hunting, fishing and whaling. The Mapuche and Quechua contest this landscape of mineral-rich deserts, bountiful central grasslands, and treasure-laden wastes.

Settlements: Mapuche, Quechua
Outlaws: Comanchero, Pistolero

Hurry your men. If we die, we die fighting.
We are close to victory. Be wary of enemy attacks.
You should study the tactics of your enemy. You need more cannon.
Steal horses if you have to, but get more horsemen into that fight.
Men and rifles are what you need. Where are your foot warriors?
This battle favors our enemy. You should withdraw.
The spirits want war. The battle draws in many tribes.
See how they throw away men in useless conflicts.
My father would be proud to give me his name after a battle like that.
My warriors will have this battle won quickly.
Your warriors arrived just in time, as I planned.
Our enemy has help. I fear their combined force may be too strong.
My plans for siege are already in progress.
My warriors will be mounted, and will be here soon.
I will have my people train more foot warriors.
My people do not have the resources for that.
The spirits will not allow that.
My warriors are elsewhere. I have no men to help you.
The spirits prevent me from doing that.
My force is not big enough. I will not send them into slaughter.
Our enemy is sly. They have destroyed a post.
The journey here has not been kind to these British people. There is not much fight in them.
It will not be long before these Dutchmen are mourning their dead.
The French will soon be driven from these lands forever.
Watch as these Germans are driven before our warriors.
See how their warriors fall. This so-called empire can never last.
If only all of our enemies fell as easily as these Portuguese.
The Russian hordes are no match for our superior warriors.
Soon all of the Spanish will vanish from these lands.
These Aztecs will feast on no bones except their own.
It saddens me to crush my Native brothers.
Their voyage has made these British strong.
These Dutch fight with the strength of the buffalo.
Where do the French find such power?
These Ottomans are stronger than I expected.
It pains me that I underestimated these Portuguese.
The strength of the Russians is great.
The spirits give strength to these Spanish.
The reputation of the Aztecs is true. They are quite strong.
The spirits have been kind to my brothers. Their strength is formidable.
Be careful you are not devoting too many resources to advancing in age. The battle ahead will be long.
It would seem our enemy values the superiority of Native warriors.
Why do you linger behind? Advance in age or our enemy will have the advantage.
A bold move, advancing in age so quickly. But make sure you balance your resources.
I hope that being the last to advance in age is part of a strategy and not just dragging your feet.
You have my thanks for your help.
That is how we deal with enemies who sneak like a snake in the grass.
Our enemy has lost his hold over my Native brothers.
That is how to clean the scourge of settlement from our lands.
With this post down, our enemy will lose sway in this area.
I have failed to liberate my brothers.
Our enemy has grown strong. Not even I could destroy that town.
Our enemy continues to profit from fouling these lands.
My war chief is down and I can not collect treasures.

I cannot continue against such odds.
It would be advantageous for you to send help here.
Many men are attacking my town.
Welcome. Follow my lead if you want to win.
I see you think you are ready for a bigger challenge.
It is probably better that you choose an easier game.
I hope you play as well now as you did the last time we met.
I may yet have something to learn from someone who leads like you did last time.
Your last effort disgraced the spirits. Try harder this time.
You will need to do much better this time to keep up with my score.
I remember these lands. That can only add to our tactical advantage.
Do not drag me down this time.

Their voyage across the sea has made these British strong.
I would not have believed these Frenchmen to be so strong.
These Germans have more fight than I had hoped.

These Portuguese have the strength of the buffalo.

The reputation of the Aztecs is well-deserved.
It is no surprise that these Natives are fierce warriors.
How can we be losing to these weak British?

I am puzzled by our failure to rout these weak Frenchmen.
These Germans are weak. We should be doing better.

You have the strength of a bear, but we are still behind.

I'll forgive that, but don't steal from my people again.
I see you have found a warrior to help you.
That wood will help you to expand your town.
You are wise to keep us ahead of their Native settlements.
That extra trading post will give us an economic advantage.

I know the power of these people. They will help us in our struggle.

This will help me to crush our enemy.

These walls will help to defend my people.

I see you have fought many battles since the last time we met.

It makes me feel good to lift the yoke off my Native brothers.

I promise you an honorable death.
It seems you think you are ready for a bigger challenge.

Keep those people safe, or they will become part of my tribe.
No amount of wood will keep my warriors out of your town.

The power of my people grows with every passing second.

More food to feed my people.

The mighty Aztecs do not need artillery. But you do.

Train more cavalry. Cuauhtemoc's warriors like the strange, hornless deer.
The mighty Aztecs run their enemies down on foot. But you must train cavalry if you wish to do the same.
You waste blood in that fight - you need more infantry.
The Aztec Empire is built on infantry and blood. Train more foot warriors.
If you insist on sacrificing your warriors, please do so at the temple.
Retreat -- you waste your warriors on the battlefield!
The stones of the battlefield drink the life of your army. Run away until you are stronger.
The battle you enter will be bloody, and while Cuauhtemoc relishes blood, he relishes victory more.
Retreat, the gods are not nourished when your blood is spilt on the battlefield.
Good, our enemies gather together so that we may slaughter them all at once.
Let the blood of our warriors and our foes mix and nourish the gods.
Cuauhtemoc has never garlanded so many so quickly.
Cuauhtemoc has captured many enemies for sacrifice.
An easy victory. More blood for the gods of the Aztecs.
Cuauhtemoc has turned defeat into triumph again!
Our enemies were like the stars, but Cuauhtemoc waded through blood to earn his victory.
The gods favor those who make sacrifice to them. Many lives were lost in that fight.
That fight was too fast. Cuauhtemoc lacked time to capture sacrifices.
Many went to the afterlife, but Cuauhtemoc prevailed.
Cuauhtemoc will have many sacrifices after this battle.
The pipiltin called Cuauhtemoc away for this?!
Cuauhtemoc will crush our enemies in the coming battle.
After the enemy throw themselves on Aztec blades, Cuauhtemoc will return to the temple.
The battle turns. Cuauhtemoc thanks you.
Cuauhtemoc is glad your army arrived. He was beginning to consider the knife for himself.
They enemy bands together! They fear Cuauhtemoc - and they should!
Artillery? What is this 'artillery' you speak of?
Cuauhtemoc will comply as best he can.
What need have Aztecs for artillery? Cuauhtemoc will show you a different kind of 'artillery.'
You joke with Cuauhtemoc, yes? The Aztecs ride no beasts.
Cuauhtemoc will send his fastest warriors.
Cavalry? The Aztecs do not borrow the strength of beasts.
Of course Cuauhtemoc will train infantry.
Infantry? What else from the Aztecs?
What else could Cuauhtemoc train except infantry?
Cuauhtemoc does not like to share.
Rodents and worms have eaten our supplies. Dark times are ahead.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors labor in the fields... they cannot fight now.
No warriors can be spared. Cuauhtemoc has... religious matters to attend to.
There is unrest in the Empire. Cuauhtemoc can spare no warriors.
This is prevented by happenings beyond even Cuauhtemoc's power.
Cuauhtemoc would, but greater forces prevent it.
The greater law does not allow Cuauhtemoc to do this.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors have bled out their lives. Their corpses would be of little use to you.
Cuauhtemoc does not have enough warriors to send.
Ask again later, Cuauhtemoc may have soldiers for you then.
Bah! They have destroyed a Trading Post. They will pay in blood!
Soon the rebel Aztec leader will grovel at Cuauhtemoc's feet, begging for merciful death.
We will grind the British into dust, like so much corn.
Gold cannot save the Dutch from the wrath of Cuauhtemoc.
The French will find that Cuauhtemoc is merciless.
The blood of Haudenosaunee warriors will soon redden the temple steps.
Cuauhtemoc will feed the heaps of Ottoman corpses to his menagerie.
The Russian hordes could not hope to bear up under the might of the Aztecs.
The Spanish could never hope to defeat Emperor Cuauhtemoc and the Aztecs.
These traitor Aztecs are stronger than Cuauhtemoc expected.
Cuauhtemoc blames you for letting the British thrive.
How did the Dutch become so powerful? Do they also make sacrifices to the gods?
The French do well. Cuauhtemoc can not tolerate this.
Who would expect such strength from the Germans? Not Cuauhtemoc.
The Haudenosaunee surprise Cuauhtemoc with their strength.
The Ottomans are strong... it must be their coffee.
The Portuguese are stronger than expected. Good, Cuauhtemoc needed a challenge.
Cuauhtemoc has learned that the only thing worse than Russians are more Russians.
Even when the Spanish are few, they are powerful.
You advance quickly. Cuauhtemoc should not have lingered so long over his rituals.
Cuauhtemoc must spill blood to catch up. Blood!
Who are you to advance so quickly - a descendant of Quetzalcoatl?
Our enemy seeks allies here. It will end badly. Trust Cuauhtemoc.
Alliances are fragile. Cuauhtemoc is not concerned that our enemy trusts in them.
Cuauhtemoc trusts no one but himself. Let our enemy forge his foolish alliances.
Our enemy has created an alliance for us to break.
There are no warriors in the first Age. Warriors bring death. Death wins wars!
You have spent long enough in the first Age.
Advance in Age or be crushed like an overripe melon.
You are too slow to be worthy of life. Advance or die.
Advance in Age soon - Cuauhtemoc can carry you no longer.
Soon it will be too late. Advance or die.
If you have no use for your villagers, send them to Cuauhtemoc. He has ideas for them.
Why are you so far behind Cuauhtemoc?
You are too fast for us all. Cuauhtemoc is yet mired in the first Age.
Be careful. He who rushes forward exposes his back.
Good. Soon you will have many warriors to bring death to our enemies. You are training warriors, yes?
The omens in the sky whisper of your greatness.
You are the first to advance in Age. Now death shall reign among our foes.
Finally you have caught up with Cuauhtemoc.
You had better not be so slow again. Cuauhtemoc cannot always protect you.
You are slower than the sloth in Cuauhtemoc's menagerie.
Finally. Does your heart beat as slowly as you advance in Age?
Cuauhtemoc will make sacrifices in your name so you can advance in Age more quickly next time.
Cuauhtemoc has saved us all. You are welcome.
They are broken! Now Cuauhtemoc goes for the throat.
No alliances! Cuauhtemoc does not allow them!
Cuauhtemoc has broken the enemy Native alliance here.
Now these Natives may consider an alliance with Cuauhtemoc. He would like that. Very much.
Out! Out! Cuauhtemoc has chased the enemy from this village.
Cuauhtemoc reigns over this ruin in darkness and smoke.
Smoke and fire! Our enemies flee Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors dance in the rubble of our enemy's town. Slay them, my warriors! Slay!
They shall not trade here anymore. So says Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs.
There can be no trade if Cuauhtemoc forbids it.
Come! Build a Trading Post here. Cuauhtemoc commands it.
Why did the enemy fools think that any would want the goods peddled here?
If a building can be sacrificed, Cuauhtemoc has sacrificed this Trading Post.
Bah... Cuauhtemoc could not destroy our enemy's alliance with this tribe.
Cuauhtemoc must regroup to attack the Trading Post in the Native village again.
Emperor Cuauhtemoc cannot be defeated... yet he was.
Cuauhtemoc has discovered that our enemy's buildings are protected by dark magic.
Unbelievable. This Trading Post somehow survived Cuauhtemoc's attacks.
When will this Trading Post fall to the might of the Aztec Empire?
What incompetence! Cuauhtemoc's war chief has fallen.
Someone or something has slain Cuauhtemoc's war chief. The gods found him unworthy.
The water is bitter. Our food is bitter. Nothing can save Cuauhtemoc.
Send an army here or you will find only gloriously-fallen Aztec corpses.
The city is in flame. All is darkness and destruction. Can even you save Cuauhtemoc?
Quick! Send your armies to Cuauhtemoc's city!
Cuauhtemoc's city shall soon fall. When it does, your city may follow.
I am Cuauhtemoc. Cuauhtemoc is the Aztec Empire.
I am Emperor Cuauhtemoc. The Aztecs stand ready to conquer.
Cuauhtemoc does not want to hear your cries when the enemies attack with fury in their hearts.
Perhaps easier enemies shall be more to your taste. They certainly are to Cuauhtemoc's...
How have you been since last we met? Since you crushed Cuauhtemoc's people under your heel.
Cuauhtemoc bows before no one save the gods... are you their messenger?
Hmmm... Cuauhtemoc wonders if you will be better now than when last we met.
Cuauhtemoc can not carry you this time. Stand on your own or die.
We do like battling here, don't we?
The blood spilled this time had better not be Cuauhtemoc's.
Once more we bring battle and bloodshed to our enemies! Death!
My war chief has returned, like Quetzalcoatl. But without the fangs. Or feathers. Or divinity.
Cuauhtemoc sees no army in the enemy city. Perhaps they have all been fed to the gods?
The enemy has not built any barracks... either they are foolish or they have built it elsewhere. Cuauhtemoc suspects they are foolish.
There is no barracks here. Why anyone would not want Infantry mystifies Cuauhtemoc.
The scouts of Cuauhtemoc have found no stable. Our enemy may have given up on the strange horse-beasts.
Cuauhtemoc sees no stable. Good. Those 'horses' make Cuauhtemoc... nervous.
Take this gold. Do not waste it.
Gold from the coffers of the Aztecs.
Gold, jade, and furs. These will bring you Coin.
This tribute is backwards. You should be sending Coin to Cuauhtemoc.
Grain, fruit and cocoa for Cuauhtemoc's friend.
Cuauhtemoc has sent you a treat - the flesh of captured warriors. Ha! Cuauhtemoc makes a joke!
A gift of food. Could you spare a villager to assist in a teeny-tiny sacrifice that Cuauhtemoc needs to make? A small one will do.
Cuauhtemoc is unaccustomed to sending tribute. Here - take your filthy food.
Take these animal carcasses. They are bled dry.
Here is some wood. Cuauhtemoc builds in stone.
Here is some wood. Carve Cuauhtemoc a mask. What? You use it for buildings? For weapons? What a waste.
What need does Cuauhtemoc have of mere Wood? Take it.
After you get this wood, have your carpenters make a tzompantli so you may display your skulls.
Wood for your fires and your buildings. But especially your fires!
Cuauhtemoc's heart beats strongly - he marches to war!
Cuauhtemoc will capture many for sacrifice after the coming battle.
Cuauhtemoc can already hear the screaming...
Aztec muscle will flatten this base as if it had never been.
Watch the settlers flee... run settlers run! You cannot escape the knife of Cuauhtemoc!
There will be nothing but smoldering grass and rubble when Cuauhtemoc is done with the enemy's town.
Aztec thews will reduce the enemy's town to rubble. And its people to corpses - or captives!
Cuauhtemoc no longer suffers the alliance of this minor tribe with our enemies.
Burn! Burn! There can be no trade without Cuauhtemoc's consent. Burn!
Cuauhtemoc does not trust your wisdom, but he shall fight alongside you.
Cuauhtemoc thinks your ranks look a little thin. His warriors will come to fill them out.
Cuauhtemoc does not want to miss the coming bloodshed. Wait for his army!
The Aztec armies will group here. Get out of the way.
The walls of Tenochtitlan are bursting... Cuauhtemoc is founding a new city.
Begin the songs and music to bless the new city of the Aztecs!
I shall make a great ritual! My new city can not bless itself!
Though he has been burned in the past, Cuauhtemoc shall attempt an alliance with the Natives here.
Cuauhtemoc will speak with these Natives. If they do not agree to ally with him he shall slay... er... he means that he will ask again, nicely.
Cocoa, fine cloth, precious metals... sacrificial animals... all for sale at this new Trading Post.
Cuauhtemoc thinks it is time the world beheld the splendors of the Aztecs. He shall construct a Trading Post.
Cuauhtemoc's soldiers shall defend this building. Or die trying.
Cuauhtemoc will defend this building no matter how many lives it costs.
Cuauhtemoc will hold this area for 52 years!
Cuauhtemoc's warriors shall fight here. They shall die here. Cuauhtemoc himself shall die here if he must.
Cuauhtemoc fights for this alliance. These Natives have proven loyal. Their hearts are strong.
Cuauhtemoc shall not let the enemy sabotage his alliance with these Natives.
The enemy shall not set foot into this town until the last of Cuauhtemoc's warriors are dead.
Cuauhtemoc shall defend this town until the sun no longer rises.
Mighty Cuauhtemoc does not need the goods traded here, but he shall not deprive you of them.
This Trading Post shall stand. So says Cuauhtemoc, Lord of the Aztecs.
Coin? Take it. What do the gods care for gold? They want lives!
My people, we will send gold to our ally. So says Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs.
Warriors toiled long in the fields for this food. Do not waste what Cuauhtemoc sends you.
The chinampas overflow with food. Cuauhtemoc shall send you his leftovers.
Cuauhtemoc requires little Wood. You may have what he does not need.
Cuauhtemoc's people will be cold tonight.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors rush to battle. The thunder you hear is their feet!
Cuauhtemoc sends all the warriors he can spare!
So many sacrifices, so little time.
If you had to choose between your own life and the sun never rising again, which would you choose? Cuauhtemoc is not evil. He allows others to be selfless.
Come to the next renewal ceremony, Cuauhtemoc will  spare no expense to ... entertain you.
Sometimes Cuauhtemoc imagines that he controls little men, no bigger than his thumb. He makes them scurry and fight and die. Cuauhtemoc needs to lay off the Ololiuhqui.
Cuauhtemoc needs gold. Send Cuauhtemoc coin!
Send Cuauhtemoc whatever coin you feel he is worthy of. He will not be at all angry if it is too little ... not angry at all...
Food! Cuauhtemoc demands a feast of food!
Cuauhtemoc needs wood to build a fire on the chest of a warrior sacrifice.
Cuauhtemoc needs wood to burn sacrifices-- er... to build buildings and weapons.
Cuauhtemoc is grateful for your help in slaying our hated enemy.
Cuauhtemoc had the situation well in hand. He needed no help.
Cuauhtemoc did not ask for your help.
Cuauhtemoc shall not waste this gift of coin.
This food shall nourish Cuauhtemoc's people. Cuauhtemoc thanks you.
The Aztec people are grateful for your assistance.
Finally you arrive. If you had not shown up when you did, Cuauhtemoc would have been finished.
Cuauhtemoc did not need your warriors. But since they have marched so far it would be a shame for them to leave.
Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the mighty Aztecs, thanks you for your fitting tribute.
Ahh.... Good. This wood will burn in the hearths of the Aztecs. The fire god will be pleased.
No! It can't be! No traitor Aztec chieftain could defeat Emperor Cuauhtemoc!
Bah! The British! Cuauhtemoc spits on them!
These Dutch, they are not all about Banks and trade...
Cuauhtemoc hopes the French are as merciful as they are strong.
How could we stop the Germans? Their uhlans run amuck!
Cuauhtemoc fears that the Haudenosaunee have more surprises in store.
Strong artillery. Strong infantry. Even strong coffee! The Ottomans are unstoppable.
The Portuguese crush us... Cuauhtemoc did not seek this much challenge.
We are doomed by relentless Russians.
Who would have expected the Spanish to defeat the Aztecs so easily?
No! Cuauhtemoc refuses to believe his pathetic Aztec rival is beating him! It is not so!
Cuauhtemoc has made sacrifice after sacrifice. And still the weak British prevail.
How do the Dutch defeat Cuauhtemoc?
The French are winning. The only answer to this humiliation is blood! More blood!
Cuauhtemoc must not allow the Germans a victory. Though it may be out of his hands.
The Haudenosaunee slaughter us. Cuauhtemoc is unaccustomed to being on the pointy end of the knife.
If the Ottomans were more powerful they could end this now. Instead they make Cuauhtemoc linger.
How! How can the Portuguese beat us? With numbers? With gunpowder? Hmm ... that is probably it.
The Russians drown us, but how? Cuauhtemoc blames you.
No! The Spanish are so few! How could they possibly defeat Cuauhtemoc?
Cuauhtemoc can stomach no more blood. Cuauhtemoc is so funny. He loves blood. But we are losing.
We are losing. How can a king be as weak as you?
Blood flows down the temple steps! We are winning!
Cuauhtemoc has concealed his power well. Now the victory seems like your doing. No thanks necessary.
This victory is Cuauhtemoc's, but you may bask in his reflected glory.
Come with Cuauhtemoc to the temple. It is time to end this war.
Emperor Cuauhtemoc wishes to end it. The obsidian knife is ready.
Cuauhtemoc can fight no longer. He will be unsuitable for sacrifice if the fighting continues.
What will convince you to stop? Should Cuauhtemoc hand you the obsidian knife?
Look - a glowing ear of corn in the sky - it sheds sparks like drops of blood... this is a sign. It is over.
Cowards! They fear to face Cuauhtemoc's armies at the time of his choosing.
The enemy allies with the Natives here. Cuauhtemoc cannot allow this.
Cuauhtemoc refuses to let the enemy monopolize trade here.
They build alliances with the Natives. They are out after Cuauhtemoc!
Good. Cuauhtemoc's foes are denied that tribe's loyalty.
Bah, why bother with Trading Posts?
Your first treasure. Take it as Cuauhtemoc's gift.
Cuauhtemoc thinks you are out to get all the treasures... yes... all the treasures.
Cuauhtemoc could have used that coin.
Cuauhtemoc could have used that food.
Fine! Take all the treasures! Leave none for Cuauhtemoc!
When you have no more use of that Native, send him to Cuauhtemoc.
Villagers? Take them. Cuauhtemoc wants warriors.
The more Native tribes we ally with, the fewer our enemies have to turn against us.
Cuauhtemoc hopes that you spending resources on your army too. Fruits and blankets make poor weapons.
Cuauhtemoc hopes that you have enough wood to train warriors after building that wall.
Cuauhtemoc cannot leave the Natives here to ally with his enemies.
The mighty Aztecs share their goods with the world.
Cuauhtemoc finds treasure in the wilderness.
This treasure in your town must be tribute for Cuauhtemoc.
All the treasures of the wilderness are tribute to Cuauhtemoc and the Aztecs!
Cuauhtemoc has rescued a Native, who will make a fine scout.
Cuauhtemoc has rescued villagers...hist! Cuauhtemoc can hear their beating hearts.
This wood will make fine maquahuitl.
Cuauhtemoc cares not for alliances, but better Cuauhtemoc than his enemies.
Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs, Master of Trade!
Walls... the better to keep Cuauhtemoc's people safe.
We will win if enough time passes - Cuauhtemoc shall begin offering hearts to the gods for our victory!
No defeat is so great that it cannot be washed away by blood.
Cuauhtemoc sees you have won battles since we met. He celebrates with a sacrifice!
You grow more experienced with each battle. Cuauhtemoc offers thanks to the gods.
One of these Trading Posts must fall!
Cuauhtemoc will feed your souls to the hungry gods.
Cuauhtemoc was wrong about you. You would make a fine sacrifice.
Bah! Sacrifice at the temple is one thing, but on the battlefield...
Cuauhtemoc cannot lose! This must be an evil dream sent by the gods.
You are no challenge to mighty Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc can feel the blood of your people running down his arms already.
What made you think that battle was a good idea?
Cuauhtemoc asks... do you prefer a slow death or a swift one?
You may flee... Cuauhtemoc is not without mercy. Who is Cuauhtemoc kidding?
Your warriors have turned the battle. Cuauhtemoc wonders what you shall demand for your help.
Cuauhtemoc's enemies band together. They fear him!
Rush headlong into death! Cuauhtemoc awaits.
What? Already you advance in Age! This displeases Cuauhtemoc very much.
Bah... Cuauhtemoc does not fear you, why should he fear your allies?
Do not think you can turn these Natives against Cuauhtemoc!
This town is destroyed, but Cuauhtemoc will find another lake and another cactus and another snake-eating eagle.
Cuauhtemoc did not need that Trading Post.
Are your people too frightened of Cuauhtemoc to advance in Age?
You are still in the first Age? Perhaps Cuauhtemoc will ensure you never see the second one.
Cuauhtemoc wonders why you cling to such primitive ways.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors are stronger than yours. His farms are more productive. His carpenters are more skilled. What hope do you have?
When you rush ahead, Cuauhtemoc has a good shot at your back.
Young corn grows quickly. Cuauhtemoc will cut you down.
Welcome to the wars. This is the Age where Cuauhtemoc will begin to destroy you.
Aha! Cuauhtemoc told his ally you were still here. His ally did not believe him.
Your town is far from everyone else... no one can hear your screams...
Bah! After he crushes your town Cuauhtemoc has a long walk to destroy your allies.
Ah... good. After Cuauhtemoc destroys your town he will not have far to march to finish your ally.
Try again and fail - again! So says Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc cannot suffer these alliances to exist.
None may trade without Cuauhtemoc's say.
I am Cuauhtemoc, Lord of all Aztecs. And you are not Quetzalcoatl.
Ahhh...It is a fine day for Emperor Cuauhtemoc to nourish the gods by sacrificing your warriors.
Kneel before Emperor Cuauhtemoc and he will let you choose the manner of your own death.
I am Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs. Cuauhtemoc will enjoy placing your skull in the tzompantli.
It is good to admit weakness. Perhaps you should just hand yourself over to Cuauhtemoc for sacrifice right now.
You must enjoy spilling your blood in this land. So does Cuauhtemoc.
Stacking the odds in your favor? Cuauhtemoc sees that your efforts are fruitless.
What? Cuauhtemoc was not enough of a challenge? He does not need a new ally to defeat the likes of you!
Cuauhtemoc's war chief returns. He lusts for vengeance.
You will not gather many treasures with him.
Cuauhtemoc has spotted your warriors. The gods thirst for their blood.
No, no, the temple is over here. Attack near it so Cuauhtemoc will not have far to drag the bodies.
Why do your warriors attack Cuauhtemoc? Has some war begun he did not know about?
No one spills the blood of Cuauhtemoc's people except Cuauhtemoc!
Cuauhtemoc sees you have come to negotiate your surrender.
This army is too small to conquer me, but almost too large to capture for sacrifice. Almost.
Your warriors scurry like insects in Cuauhtemoc's city. Ow! Stinging insects!
The blood of so few can only cause the sun to rise for a week or two. Send more.
It is good of you to leave tribute for Cuauhtemoc. He will make your death as painless as he can.
Cuauhtemoc cannot resist warning you of his attack so he may smell the fear in your sweat.
That thunder? It is the blood rushing in your ears that you hear.
The Aztec army comes. Surrender so that Cuauhtemoc can more easily take you to the waiting altar.
A sign glows in the sky, an ear of corn shedding sparks like blood.
There is always room for sacrifice.
Cuauhtemoc concedes. The treasure of the Aztecs is at the bottom of the lake.
Give Cuauhtemoc an honorable death so that his blood may nourish the gods and his flesh feed your menagerie.
Before you cut down Cuauhtemoc's people, would you care to share a cup of chocolate?
Burn the bridges! Pour the treasure into the lake! The Aztecs are finished.
No! Cuauhtemoc will never surrender! Unless you let him...
Cuauhtemoc did not shed enough blood to ensure victory. It is the end of all things.
The Aztecs are defeated. Will the sun ever rise again?
Those treasures cannot save you from Cuauhtemoc's obsidian blade.
You amass wealth. All the more for Cuauhtemoc when he conquers you.
Your collection of treasures may comfort you in the grave.
Cuauhtemoc will enjoy making you pay for stealing that treasure.
Be careful of treachery from those you protect.
Gathering wood for your funeral pyre?
Cuauhtemoc sees a wall. You are properly frightened.
No wall can save you from Cuauhtemoc.
The Aztecs are well known for their alliances with neighboring peoples.
Cuauhtemoc claims all trade in this land.
This land is ripe with treasures that belong to Emperor Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc laughs at your sluggish treasure gathering.
Cuauhtemoc loves the Natives of this land.
These villagers are hearty. They will work hard.
A cache of wood, the better to burn you with!
In Cuauhtemoc's experience, such alliances can be deadly. Enjoy!
A Trade Post. Now Cuauhtemoc knows where to find you.
If you cannot defeat the mighty Aztecs on the battlefield, why do you think this will work?
Good, my warriors like a challenge. It gets the blood up.
Cuauhtemoc's victory is immanent. If you surrender now, you will have the honor to be the first at the altar.
Cuauhtemoc opens the gates to his city so you may view its splendor as you die.
Cuauhtemoc thinks that perhaps you have been seeking treasure at the bottom of a lake.
You climb the steps to glory. Cuauhtemoc waits at the top.
Do not imagine that Cuauhtemoc will cower just because you are more powerful than when he last faced you.
Fear for us, O ally. Harm and evil come now near us!
Better were it to go fasting than to bear this dreadful burden - we stand to lose in less than one minute.
A monstrous story; we are but one minute from losing this war.
Do not fear for me, O ally. Harm and evil shall come no more near us!
By the shining water and the drifting grass lands, we shall win in less than one minute.
From my brain the thought of vengeance, but from my heart the simple need for more siege.
It would be a great achievement if you could bring more siege weapons to this battle.
In these days of evil spirits, the fields of battle need more horsemen from you.
We fight onward, in solemn manner, and need from you more horsed warriors.
When I speak to the foe he trembles, the need in battle is for more foot warriors.
Our war clubs are swinging, our foes are cracking, but to win the war we need more foot warriors from you.
You are like a man from a dream awakened, only to face a terrible blow. Withdraw, my ally, withdraw.
The shattered sky above us breaks! Do not join us in this doomed fight, my ally!
A battle rages. The sky we tread beneath bends and throws itself in fury.
We join and raise our fists against the heavens; a great battle rages here!
The clouds are swept from heaven. By our hand the enemy has passed from the fields, as we expected.
The tens and eights of our enemy have fallen in that battle, as I knew they would.
We threw them on the ground before us, our foes in rows vanquished.
A moody melancholy takes me, with this victory that once seemed unlikely.
Curious eyes stare about us. How did we win that battle, which should have been a loss?
In many games of skill and hazard, one would have to reach far to find a battle like this one. How did we win it?
Mighty move our forces, our foe's heart shall be swept with ice.
I enter this fray full of eagerness.
This battle will be excellent, full of victory for us and defeat for them.
We shall circle our foes with confidence. They shall lose this fight.
Timely and potent your arrival. The tide of battle flows now in our favor.
It is good you are back from your wanderings; you are needed to turn the flow of this battle.
Enters through the door a burning firebrand; another foe has joined the fray.
The enemy has seized the war club in this fray; we may fare poorly.
This is where we agree, yes.
On my nation, on my honor, yes.
Ay, though panting under heavy burdens.
Ay, the forges shall fire, the siege made.
I shall build the siege weapons you need, ally.
Ay, our horse riders shall tread, and the grasses bend.
You shout for horse riders, and horse riders I shall give you!
Beneath shaggy eyebrows, I gaze. Your horse riders are on their way.
Ay, although to the land of ghosts and shadows they may walk, foot warriors we shall train.
The foot warriors shall journey to your side.
Yes. And loosely shall our foes be scattered, when my foot warriors arrive to help you.
Our supplies and resources are little more than smoke wreaths. I cannot comply.
My reserves are too low to meet your need, ally.
I have not the food, wood, nor coin to help you.
To your request, we cannot accede.
The fallen leaves of last year... No.
Have your eyes been blinded by the dark and bright? I have no warriors to help you.
You must find strength within. I lack an army to help you.
Alas. I cannot. Better were it to go fasting than to bear such a heavy burden.
Although the eyes of wolves glare at me, I cannot do that.
My young soldiers are insufficient in number to meet your request.
My forces are too depleted. No.
I have too few warriors to help you now.
Enemies have journeyed to one of our trading posts. It is laid to waste.
We cannot win that way after all.
The Aztecs have traveled a long and weary journey, but it looks now finally to be at a dark end.
The Aztecs have almost been destroyed.
Not so long and wide the world is... my wrath has reached the British empire!
The British are almost gone, as ducks in the winter.
If the powerful Dutch go on thus, we shall tear them to pieces.

Andes: fight for control over trade and native allies at the feet of the mighty Andes mountains.

Settlements: Quechua, Mapuche, Zapotec
Outlaws: Pistolero, Renegado
Maya barbed spearmen. Good against cavalry or buildings.
Zapotec warrior armed with a shield and a sword.
Cherokee skirmisher that is accurate at long range.
Cree rifleman with a good line of sight and long range.
Long-range, accurate native archer. Good against infantry.
Nootka warrior armed with a wooden club.
Cheyenne horseman armed with a spear.
Comanche ranged cavalry. Good against cavalry.
Ship carrying massive amounts of Coin, but has no attack.
